_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at your facility: Safety of the public and environment as well as the safety of their own employees is top priority. The facility complies with the NFPA 58-2011 requirements for LP-Gas storage facilities as adopted by the Indiana State Register. Additionally, the facility complies with applicable federal and local laws with respect to the safe handling of propane. The facility meets the requirements of the codes and laws with its practices and design to ensure there is minimal risk of an accidental release. If an emergency were to occur, procedures are in place to notify the local Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency. The terminal is registered with CHEMTREC an emergency call center that provides information and assistance in the event of an emergency. There is also a 24-hour company emergency number that can assist with coordinating emergency responders and recommend courses of action in emergency scenarios.

A description of your facility and the regulated substances handled:  The Mentone Propane Company terminal is a wholesale propane distribution terminal for storage and distribution of propane to local propane marketers. The facility's permanent storage consists of two 60,000-gallon tanks and two 30,000-gallon tanks with associated loading and unloading equipment. Additionally, there is one 500-gallon tank used for building heating and one 334-gallon tank used for compressor liquid trap evacuation. Propane (UN 1075) is classified as a flammable gas. Typically, propane is received in rail tank cars that are unloaded at the facility using compressors. And if necessary, propane can be offloaded from cargo liners using on-board pumps. Propane is loaded into customer truck transports or company bobtail trucks using the facility's pumping and metering equipment.

The worst-case and alternative release scenarios:  The worst case scenario, as defined by the EP

A, is the failure of one 60,000-gallon storage tank when filled to the greatest amount allowed (88% at 60?F), resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite, and public receptors are within the distance to the endpoint. Equation C-1 from the EPA's RMP Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis was used to determine the hazard distance for the worst case scenario for determination of the public receptors. The alternative release scenario, as determined by the Potential Failure Modes and Effects Analysis (PFMEA) a quantitative study of all potential hazards, is a vehicular accident caused by driver error resulting  in breaking a section of pipe, and creating a vapour cloud that ignites after a short time. The team performing the PFMEA consisted of a group of management and engineers with experience in the design, operation, and maintenance of propane facilities.  

As well, a third party engineering company has conducted a quantitative risk assessment and layer of protection analysis of the worst case and alternative case scenarios. The analyses determined that the location risk for each of the public receptors were acceptable according to the 2008 modified Major Industrial Accidents Council of Canada (MIACC) Guidelines created by the Canadian Society for Chemical Engineering, Process Safety Management Division for risk acceptability criteria. The MIACC guidelines are acceptable risk criteria published in numerous jurisdictions including the United Kingdom, Netherlands, Australia, and Canada. 

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:  The facility complies with the EPA's accident prevention rule as per 40 CFR Part 68, the OSHA PSM standard, and all applicable state and local codes and regulations. The propane system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with state laws adopting NFPA 58-2011.  

Five-year accident history:  The Mentone propane facility has neve

r had an accident involving propane that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or dwellings in place. 

The emergency response program:  All personnel, drivers, and contractors receive emergency response procedures training before being allowed on site with drivers also receiving training on the facility loading procedures.  The emergency procedures cover all components of an emergency including facility shutdown, alerting local emergency services, and evacuation. In the event of an emergency, the typical response would be through 911. Terminal personnel or emergency responders may contact CHEMTREC to request information and recommendations for emergency response measures.  The emergency response plans have been coordinated with the fire department; members of the Fire Department have visited the propane facility and have reviewed the safety systems in place. The Fire Department has been given a map showing the public receptors within the hazard distance in the event of an evacuation exercise.  Emergency response equipment is inspected and tested regularly to ensure proper function.  The emergency response procedures are re-evaluated on a regular basis, as well as tested annually.

Operational and process safety systems:  The facility has been designed with failsafe systems and practices to mitigate the severity of any incident involving propane.  These safety systems and practices include:

?    Restricted access: transport loading area and storage tanks are contained within a fenced compound. The transport loading area includes pad-locked man-gates and motorized ingress/egress gates. Drivers are pre-authorized to access the facility upon completing site specific emergency preparedness training hosted by terminal personnel. Pre-authorized personnel can access the terminal via motorized access gate. The gate will open once personnel enter their Personal Identification Number (PIN) on the keypad at the entrance to the fenced compound. R

ailcar unloading equipment including compressors are locked out when personnel are not present at the facility.

?    Safety information: signage is posted throughout the facility to remind occupants to avoid hazards such as smoking and creating sources of ignition, as well as wear proper safety equipment including fire resistant clothing.  Operating procedures and emergency response procedures and phone numbers are also posted and reviewed with personnel.

?    Manual and electronic shutdown: the emergency stop system can be activated by pressing any of the emergency stop buttons located throughout the facility. The emergency stop system will shut down the entire facility, close all tank openings, and open the motorized gates.

?    Normally-closed pneumatic valves: these valves are installed in all tank openings and at all product transfer points. These valves remain closed unless a propane transfer operation is being conducted by authorized personnel.

?    Heat sensitive (thermal) devices:  the pneumatic control valves at the tank openings and at loading points are equipped with fuse plugs which will melt if a fire occurs causing the control valves to close automatically, minimizing possible product loss and isolating the tanks and shutting down loading/unloading points .Similarly the polyethylene pneumatic lines will melt in the event of a fire and drop in pneumatic pressure will cause the control valves to close.

?    Fire extinguishers: these are located throughout the facility to assist in suppressing a small fire.

?    Hose assemblies with rupture protection: the truck transfer hoses are equipped with an internal spring and closing flapper valves at both ends which will close the hose ends during a hose rupture or pull-away event, to minimize product loss.

?    Training requirements: terminal operators have several training requirements that they must complete including having a record of training for completing propane specific Certified Employee Training Program (CETP) cou

rses as designated by the National Propane Gas Association (NPGA). They must also receive training for terminal emergency procedures. All drivers must have completed the necessary CTEP courses to transfer propane as well as be trained in the site specific transfer and emergency procedures.  Only approved drivers will be able to perform loading operations at the facility. Records of personnel, driver, and contractor training are kept on file.

?    Operating procedures: detailed operating guidelines and procedures are maintained for truck loading, railcar unloading, product transfer, as well as emergency procedures.  These procedures are reviewed on a regular basis.

?    Maintenance procedures: regular maintenance and inspections of emergency and operational equipment are carried out by terminal personnel at predetermined intervals as designated in the operating guidelines to ensure all equipment is in proper condition.

?    Incident reporting: the facility has a policy in place for documenting and reporting any incidents or potential hazards. All reports are reviewed and corrective action taken as required.

Planned changes to improve safety:  Terminal and company management seek continuous improvement of operational and safety systems to minimize the risk of incidents, injuries and propane releases. This includes the ongoing training of personnel and the review and maintenance of operating guidelines and emergency procedures. Processes, procedures and facilities will be reviewed regularly and appropriate improvements to safety and operational systems will be implemented as required.
